home.userToValidate: A user has been added to your organization because they have just been trained in the carbon assessment method. Go to <link>your team page</link> to validate their account
home.title: Completing your impact assessment will allow you to:

info.0: Understand the impact assessment of your establishment

message.core:
Welcome to COUNT, the first ecological impact calculator dedicated to movie theaters.
This tool was developed by the association CUT! Cinema United for Transition, in cooperation with the ABC, the association for low-carbon transition.
This initiative is supported by the French State as part of the 'Support Green Alternatives 2' program under France 2030, operated by the Banque des Territoires (Caisse des Dépôts).
CUT is supported by the CNC.
message.0: Completing your impact assessment will allow you to:
message.1: Understand the impact assessment of your establishment

categorisations.FinalClient: By the final client or an intermediary

category.title: Category
category.4: Indirect emissions associated with purchased products
category.5: Indirect emissions associated with sold products

1.1: Direct emissions from stationary combustion sources
1.2: Direct emissions from mobile combustion sources

2.2: Indirect emissions from steam, heat, or cold consumption

ressources.title: Resources
ressources.description:
The COUNT impact calculator is certified by the ABC. It was built using various emission factor sources (ADEME's Base Empreinte, EcoInvent, Boavizta, CNC, among others). Additional emission factors were specifically developed for the tool by Resilio (a link to the Resilio methodology can be added here; we will send it to you).

The calculation assumptions were based on:

- 15 comprehensive carbon assessments carried out in partnership with the CINEO cinema group

- Multiple interviews with stakeholders in the cinema sector (suppliers, integrators, independent operators, exhibition circuits, etc.) - Visits to cinemas of various types
ressources.france2030: As part of the France 2030 Plan, the 'Green Alternatives 2' initiative, endowed with €25 million over 3 waves and operated by the Banque des Territoires (Caisse des Dépôts group) in partnership with the Ministry of Culture, the Ministry of Ecological Transition, and the General Secretariat for Investment, aims to accelerate the ecological transition of cultural enterprises to make the sector a benchmark in environmental responsibility. Of the 51 applications received for the first wave of 'Green Alternatives 2', 13 projects were selected, including the one led by CUT! The jury particularly praised the strong collective ambition serving the ecological transition of cinema and audiovisual, embracing the entire value chain of cinema, with the sponsorship of charismatic personalities from the industry.

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.exports: Take into account emissions that have not been validated
glossary.exportsDescription: Within a Bilan Carbone®, you can choose to display all the emissions you have entered, or only those that have been validated by a validator.
glossary.caUnitsDescription: Specify the unit you wish to use for turnover figures.

duplicateDialog.title: Study duplication
duplicateDialog.description:
Do you want to duplicate this study? You will be redirected to the study creation page, all fields will be pre-filled with the information from the study that you will be able to edit, and once the creation is validated, the entire study and its emission sources will be duplicated. Documents attached to the original study will not be duplicated. Please note that after duplication, the emission sources of the newly created study will need to be validated again in order to appear in the results.

Studies are independent after duplication, any modification made in one will not be reflected in the other.
duplicateDialog.duplicatedDescription: Your study has been duplicated. You can find it in your {environment} environment.
duplicateDialog.otherEnvironnment: Would you like to duplicate this study in your {environment}? All information will be copied to the new study.

study.firstStudyMessage: It's time to get started! We invite you to create your first bilan.
study.validatedOnlyDescription: For each Bilan Carbone®, one or more validators can be defined. These validators are responsible for validating the sources of emissions once they have been entered by the study's contributors and editors. By default, only validated emissions appear in your results, but you can change this behaviour via the "Settings" menu.
study.withDependenciesDescription: The new Bilan Carbone® method introduces the concept of responsibility and dependency. It is strongly recommended that the results of the Bilan Carbone® are presented with and without the "Use in dependence" sub-post, as the organization is generally not in a position to act easily on this sub-post. On the other hand, this sub-component remains crucial for understanding the risks to which the organization is exposed, particularly if it is dependent on high-carbon sectors or activities. The final result should include dependency. For more information on these new concepts, please consult <link>this page</link>.
study.monetaryRatioDescription: It is strongly discouraged to use emission factors in monetary ratio when an alternative is possible. You can find more information on the <monetaryLink>methodology</monetaryLink>.
study.selectSite: Before filling in the details, choose a site

siteDeselectionModal.title: Warning: Sites with emission sources
siteDeselectionModal.description: You are trying to deselect sites that contain emission sources in the original study.
siteDeselectionModal.totalSources: {count, plural, =1 {In total, 1 emission source will not be duplicated.} other {In total, # emission sources will not be duplicated.}}
siteDeselectionModal.confirmation: Are you sure you want to continue?

glossary.title: Glossaire
glossary.validatorEmailDescription: For each Bilan Carbone®, one or more validators can be defined. These validators are responsible for validating the sources of emissions once they have been entered by the study's contributors and editors. By default, only validated emissions appear in your results, but you can change this behaviour via the "Parameters" menu.
glossary.studyDatesDescription: This is the period over which the study extends. In general, the beginning and end correspond to 1st January and 31st December of the same year.
glossary.realizationDatesDescription: This is the period during which you will be working on the study: filling in emission sources, exporting, etc. These dates are not compulsory and you can always access the study outside the indicated period.
glossary.typeDescription: The new version of the Bilan Carbone® method introduces three levels of maturity for organizations' Bilan Carbone®. For more details, please consult <link>this page</link>.
glossary.visibilityDescription: Choose whether your study should be public, i.e. accessible to all your colleagues entered on the My organization > my team page (link to the page), or private, i.e. only accessible to the people you add on the study framework page. Your organization's admins have access to all studies, whether public or private.
glossary.exportsDescription: By default, the results are returned in Bilan Carbone® format, but it is possible to obtain the results in the formats required by several other carbon accounting methods, such as the Bilan GES règlementaire, which is the French regulatory method.
glossary.controlDescription: The control mode is a data item required by certain carbon accounting methods, such as the regulatory GHG Balance or the GHG Protocol. In order to obtain the results in the formats requested by these methods, you will need to characterise the different sources of emissions when you enter them, which will determine into which of the existing categories within these methods (the equivalent of the posts and sub-posts within the Bilan Carbone® method) the emissions will be broken down. Depending on the control mode selected, the characterizations available for the different sources of emissions vary. For more details on the control modes, please consult the methodological guides for the methods in question. We strongly recommend that you use the "Operational Control" control mode, which is by far the most common.
glossary.duplicationOptionsDescription: When duplicating a study, you can choose to invite the same team members and contributors from the original study to the new one. This helps maintain collaboration continuity.

role.introduction: From this page, you can manage the members of your team involved in the Bilan Carbone®. In all cases, the administrators of your organization have access to all your studies as validators. If your study is public, members of your organization (employees, managers) automatically have read access to it. You can also add people from outside your organization via this menu.
role.Validator_description: Has full rights over the study and can validate the emission sources entered by validators, editors and contributors.
role.Editor_description: Has all rights to the study except for validation of emission sources.
role.Reader_description: Can only read the study and export its information.

family.title: Tags family
family.add: Ajouter un nouveau tag dans une famille
family.name: Label
family.deleteContent: Do you really want to delete the "{name}" tag family ? <error>All its tags will be permanently deleted.</error>
family.content: Which name do you want to give to you family ?
family.glossaryDescription:
Tags and tag families are used to identify your emission sources in order to visualize certain results later.

Once your tags are created, you can associate them with emission sources within the "Data Entry" page. Then, on the "Results" page, you can view the emissions due to a tag family or a specific tag, but you will not be able to view the emissions of two tag families simultaneously, because double counting can occur between these two tag families.

To give a concrete example, let's say there are two tag families: "Products Sold" and "Target Audiences". These two families and the tags belonging to them will allow you to visualize the distribution of your organization's emissions based on the products sold, and the same for the target audiences.

duplicate.title: Duplicate site {name} and its emission sources
duplicate.description: You can duplicate a site and/or its emission sources to one or more sites in your study. The emission sources will be duplicated. The site information (ETP, CA) will only be modified on the study and not on your general information.

perimeter.information: For more information on this section, you can refer to this documentation:

results.tagGlossary: Double count on charts by tags
results.tagGlossaryDescription: Emission sources can have multiple tags, so these are counted in each tag on this graph. It is therefore normal that you have a larger total here than in your study.

difference.button: Explanation of the differences between Bilan Carbone® and Beges export
difference.modalTitle: Explanation of the difference between the results
difference.dependance: The regulatory GHG balance does not include the sub-item "Dependent use", as the concept of dependence does not exist in the BEGES-R method
difference.waste: The regulatory Bilan GES includes all emissions due to waste recycling in the waste emitter's balance sheet, whereas the Bilan Carbone® only includes the weight of waste collection and transport in the waste emitter's balance sheet. Thus, the emission factors with a value of 41 kgCO₂e/t within the tool are those used for the Bilan Carbone®, while the values incorporating the regeneration of materials (the recycling process, for the emission factors "Recycling" or "Average end of life") are used for the BEGES-R. The emission factor displayed on the BC+ is only that used for the Bilan Carbone®, but the BEGES-R export calculations are made using the ADEME emission factors linked to recycling or average end-of-life. Here are the sources of emissions related to this topic:
difference.missingCaract1: Uncharacterized emission sources are not accounted for in the BEGES-R, which leads to undue differences with the Bilan Carbone® if you have chosen to visualize unvalidated emission sources.
difference.missingCaract2: You have not entered the characterizations for all the emission sources in your study. Please edit and add the characterization for the following emission sources:
difference.unexplainedDifference: Some differences can not be explained. Please, contact us at the <support>support</support>.

uncertainties.title: Uncertainties analytics
uncertainties.uncertainPostsTitle: Posts with the greatest uncertainties within the Bilan Carbone®

results.postEmissionPerNumberOfSources: Emissions by post based on the number of emission sources

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.uncertaintyPerPostDescription: Please note that the size of the circles on this graph is proportional to the number of emission sources that have been entered for the item, and not to the total emissions for the item (which can be seen on the x-axis). This allows you to see which items have been analysed in the greatest detail and to assess whether this is relevant in terms of the significance of the associated emissions, as it is generally more relevant to work in detail on the most significant emission items. The following graphs also illustrate this effect.
glossary.uncertaintyPerPostDescription2: Furthermore, the greater the number of emission sources within a station, the less uncertainty there will be for that station. This is because two uncertainties cancel each other out, as it is generally uncertain whether the error will be made in the same direction. To give a concrete example, when measuring two strings, it is possible to overestimate the length of the first and underestimate the length of the second. Consequently, the uncertainty about the length of the sum of the two strings will be less than the sum of the two uncertainties taken separately.

onboarding.title: Choose a reference trajectory or create your top-down trajectory
onboarding.description: Compare your situation with SBTi and SNBC reference trajectories. Follow one of these trajectories and its associated objectives or create your personalized trajectory (top-down trajectory).
onboarding.detailedInfo:
Two reference trajectories, SNBC and SBTi, are offered here. You can visualize the decarbonization trajectory that your organization should follow according to each one.



Since SNBC is divided according to the major sectors of the French economy, you must select the sector that best corresponds to you. More information about SNBC is available here.

SBTi provides a trajectory aimed at limiting global warming to 1.5°C, and a second aimed at limiting it well below 2°C. You must also choose which of these two trajectories you wish to visualize. More information about SBTi is available here.



If your reference assessment dates from a year prior to the use of BC+2.0, you can enter the reference year and associated emissions. If this assessment is already present on BC+2.0, you can select it as the reference assessment.



For each of these trajectories, the choice has been made to keep the associated carbon budget. If your emissions do not exactly follow the chosen trajectory, BC+2.0 will recalculate an adapted trajectory to avoid exceeding the initially allocated carbon budget. With each new assessment carried out, your trajectories will be updated.

onboarding.title: Add a trajectory or reduction objectives
onboarding.description: You have already created a reference trajectory but want to add others to test different hypotheses and ambition levels? You can create new trajectories, or add intermediate objectives for more detailed tracking without losing sight of the final goal!
onboarding.detailedInfo: When you enter your first top-down trajectory, the associated objectives for 2030 and 2050 will be recorded in this table. You can then detail these objectives by adding additional intermediate targets, which can apply either to all categories and sites of the Carbon Assessment® (in which case the reductions will be calculated automatically to maintain consistency with the 2030 and 2050 objectives), or to specific categories and sites. You can also enter your projected revenue growth to obtain annual reductions that account for this growth. Finally, you can add other top-down trajectories, particularly to visualize different trajectories on the previous page before choosing the one you will follow.

table.enabledGlossaryDescription: The reductions linked to actions you have enabled are taken into account on the <trajectoryLink>Reduction trajectories</trajectoryLink> page in your bottom-up trajectory. Reductions linked to disabled actions will not be visible. Enabling or disabling actions allows you to consider different scenarios to achieve your reduction objectives.

addModal.indicatorTooltipDescription: An action tracking feature is coming! You can already list your indicators and will be able to quantify and track them once the feature is released.

relevance.ReductionOutsideOrganisationValueChain: Reduction outside the organisation's value chain (Priority 2/6)
relevance.ReductionWithinOrganisationValueChain: Reduction within the organisation's value chain (Priority 1/6)
relevance.ReductionWithinOrganisationCoreBusiness: Reduction within the organisation's core business (Priority 1/6)
relevance.learnMore: For more information, please visit <link>this page</link>.

onboarding.title: Create your action plan to achieve your objectives
onboarding.description: You have already created your trajectory and associated objectives. Now you can add the actions to your transition plan that will allow you to achieve these objectives
onboarding.detailedInfo: A top-down trajectory is defined macroscopically, setting medium and long-term reduction targets. In contrast, a bottom-up trajectory is built from an action plan—a set of coherent actions that, when combined, enable emission reductions during their implementation. This page allows you to enter and characterize various actions, following the information defined in the Carbon Assessment® methodology. All this information must be recorded in a Carbon Assessment®, but it is possible to fill in some details later to test different action combinations before making final selections. A toggle in the first column of the table allows you to activate or deactivate the entered actions to see if the resulting bottom-up trajectory aligns with the chosen top-down trajectory. Once relevant actions are selected, you can complete the missing information to better characterize each action, assign a budget, specify implementation steps, and define indicators that will later help you monitor the implementation, tracking, and performance of your actions.

post.EmissionsLieesAuChangementDAffectationDe: Emissions related to land use change (LUC)
post.BiensEtMatieresEnApprocheMonetaire: Goods and materials in monetary approach
post.DeplacementsProfessionnels: Employee travel in the context of work
post.ConsommationDEnergieEnFinDeVie: Energy consumption at end of life
post.TraitementDesDechetsEnFinDeVie: Waste treatment at end of life
post.TraitementDesEmballagesEnFinDeVie: Packaging treatment at end of life
post.UtilisationEnResponsabiliteFuitesEtAutre: Responsible use - Leaks and other consumption
post.UtilisationEnDependanceFuitesEtAutresCon: Dependent use - Leaks and other consumption

glossaryDescription.DechetsDirects: This post covers all emissions linked to the management of waste produced (collection and treatment) within the organization. It is divided into different sub-posts, each covering a different category of waste.
glossaryDescription.IntrantsBiensEtMatieres: This post covers emissions linked to the various flows of goods and materials entering the organization. It is divided into different sub-posts, each covering a different category of material.
glossaryDescription.Immobilisations: All emissions linked to the purchase or long-term rental of durable goods (subject to accounting depreciation by the organization).
glossaryDescription.FinDeVie: This post covers all emissions related to the future end-of-life of products sold within the timeframe.
glossaryDescription.DeplacementsDomicileTravail: Commuting to and from work for employees working within the organization, including temporary staff, subcontractors and contractors.
glossaryDescription.DeplacementsProfessionnels: Business travel by employees in the course of their professional activity, whether or not the organization owns the means of transport, and whether or not the travel takes place during working hours.
glossaryDescription.CombustiblesFossiles: For heating, industrial processes, electricity or steam production.
glossaryDescription.CombustiblesOrganiques: For heating, industrial processes, electricity or steam production.
glossaryDescription.Electricite: For heating, routine use, industrial processes and own electricity production.
glossaryDescription.Agriculture: Enteric fermentation of ruminants, livestock waste, use of nitrogen fertilisers, etc.
glossaryDescription.EmissionsLieesAuxProcedesIndustriels: Cement production, process emissions in the semiconductor industry, etc.
glossaryDescription.FretInterne: If the departure and arrival points are part of the organizational perimeter.
glossaryDescription.ServicesEnApprocheMonetaire: Various services received, accounted for via emission factors in monetary ratios.
glossaryDescription.MatiereDestineeAuxEmballages: In order to be able to focus the transition plan's actions on packaging, a sub-post dedicated to the material used in this packaging is available.
glossaryDescription.BiensEtMatieresEnApprocheMonetaire: A sub-section is also dedicated to materials for which emission factors in monetary ratios are used.
glossaryDescription.UtilisationEnResponsabilite: Products sold by the organization within the timeframe under consideration over their entire lifespan, for which the organization is directly responsible ([in italisque] for a manufacturer of meal trays served on aircraft, the responsible use corresponds to the energy used to cool and heat the meal tray).
glossaryDescription.UtilisationEnDependance: Products sold by the organization within the timeframe under consideration over their entire lifespan, for which the organization is not directly responsible but which its activity contributes to emitting ([in italics] For a manufacturer of meal trays served in an aircraft, the dependent use corresponds to the emissions for the entire flight).

create.title: Add an emission factor
create.name: Name
create.namePlaceholder: Give a name to your emission Factor

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.detailedGESDescription: If you know the proportion of emissions due to the different GHGs for your emission factor, you can enter it using this function. The Bilan Carbone® method does not use this breakdown, as knowing the distribution of emissions across the different GHGs complicates the results without providing any useful information for building the transition plan. However, this breakdown of emissions by GHG is useful if you wish to obtain the various exports offered by BC+.

multipleDescription.introduction: Some emission factors have components, i.e. they are made up of different emissions from different activities. For example, emission factors for electricity in France are classically broken down into three components:
multipleDescription.upstream: Upstream, which takes into account emissions linked to the construction of electricity generation infrastructure and its transmission to the grid.
multipleDescription.combustion: , which takes into account emissions linked to the production of electricity itself (coal combustion, etc.).
multipleDescription.loss: Losses, which take account of losses in the form of heat during the transmission of electricity on the network.
multipleDescription.conclusion: This disaggregation is not used in the Bilan Carbone® method, but is used to break down the emissions of the various components within the categories for exports (for the regulatory GHG balance, using the same example, and if the source of emissions is "Operated", "upstream" emissions, "combustion at the power plant" and "losses" are broken down within categories 4.1, 1.2 and 4.1 respectively).. We strongly recommend that you do not use this function if you are not familiar with the allocations within the regulatory GHG balance.

glossary.post_studyContributorDescription: You must choose the item(s) and sub-item(s) within which your emission factor will be selectable.
glossary.post_emissionFactorDescription: You must choose the item(s) and sub-item(s) within which the contributor will be able to work.

table.subTitle: You can browse all the available emission factors, and create new ones

modal.confirm-edition: Are you sure you want to edit this emission factor

missingQualities.title: Add quality for manual emission factors
missingQualities.body: Hello, according to our information, you added emission factors manually when it was still impossible to enter their uncertainty. By default, for these emission factors, the qualities are considered to be "Very good", which corresponds to zero uncertainty on the emission factor. Now that this bug has been resolved, we strongly recommend that you update the emission factors concerned, which are as follows:

role.ADMIN_description: An administrator has full rights to the organization's account and to all studies for his organization (whether public or private). It is impossible to change an administrator role on a study of his organization.
role.ADMIN_description_CR: An administrator has full rights to the organization's and the organization clients' account and studies (whether public or private). It is impossible to change an administrator role on a study of his organization or one of its clients.
role.GESTIONNAIRE_description: A manager has full rights over the organization's account, but no rights over studies. He is by default reader on public studies of his organization.
role.GESTIONNAIRE_description_CR: A manager has full rights over the organization's account, but no rights over customers or studies. He is by default reader on its organization's or its clients public studies.
role.COLLABORATOR_description: A collaborator is a person trained in the Bilan Carbone® method. They have no rights to the organization's account but can create studies. They have access to their organization's public studies with the role editor by default.
role.COLLABORATOR_description_CR: A collaborator is a person trained in the Bilan Carbone® method. They have no rights to the organization's account but can create clients and studies. They only have access to their organization's or their organization clients public studies with the role editor by default.
role.DEFAULT_description: A member of the organization has no specific rights over the organization, the team or studies. By default, they are readers of all their organization's public Bilans Carbone®.
role.DEFAULT_description_CR: A member of the organization has no specific rights over the organization, the team, their clients or studies. By default, they are readers of all their organization's or their organization's clients public Bilans Carbone®.
role.Not authorized: You are not allowed to do this action
role.More than one: There must be at least one admin or manager in the organization

table.title: My team

glossary.title: Glossary
glossary.typeDescription: The type of data is a denomination introduced by the new Bilan Carbone® method, which complements the calculation of uncertainties. For more information on the different types of data, please consult <link>this page</link>.
glossary.qualityDescription: Uncertainties are now calculated using qualitative notes on the quality of the emission factor and the quality of the activity data. The scores for the emission factor are taken directly from the databases, but those for the activity data must be entered. For more information on how scores are awarded, please consult <link>this page</link>.
glossary.specificEmissionFactorQuality: You can specifically adjust the quality of the emission factor in your emission source. The generic value of the emission factor is indicated by the {marker} symbol.
glossary.versionDescription: You are modifying a study from the old BC+. As this emission factor does not exist in the version linked to your study ({bcVersion}), if you modify it, you will never be able to put it back.

deleteDialog.title: Are you sur you want to delete this emission source?
deleteDialog.description: <warning>All data entered will be permanently lost,</warning> and any contributors will no longer have access to this emission source.

duplicateDialog.title: Do you want to duplicate this broadcast source?
duplicateDialog.content: You can duplicate this broadcast source. You can then modify it.
duplicateDialog.selectSite: Please indicate for which study site you wish to duplicate this source.

error.contactSupport:
A problem has occurred. Try returning to the home page.

If this does not work, contact our support at or try to reconnect.

onboarding.title-1: Welcome to BC+! Before you start, please set up your organization
onboarding.titleDescription-1: We've pre-filled some information about your organization (association, company, ...) based on your membership with ABC. You can update your organization's name now, or at any time in BC+ via the "Organization" section.
onboarding.titleDescription-2: You can already add your team members! You'll still be able to add new people later via the "Team" section within the "Organization" menu.

step1.name: Name of my organization
step1.adminDescription: You have been trained to the Bilan Carbone® method : Thus, your have been attribued to the Admin role
step1.gestionnaireDescription: You have not been trained to the Bilan Carbone® method : Thus, your have been attribued to the Gestionnaire role

step2.crCollaboratorDescription: Create clients and realize their Bilan Carbone®
step2.gestionnaireDescription: Manages the organization's account but does not have access to studies
step2.memberDescription: Has no rights over the organization and is not necessarily trained to the Bilan Carbone® method.

checklist.title: Getting started on BC+
checklist.AddCollaboratorDetails: Add your colleagues so that they can help you draw up your organization's Bilan Carbone®.
checklist.AddClientDetails: Add your first client to start your Bilans Carbone®.
checklist.AddSiteCRDetails: Add sites to your <orga>organization</orga> or to <client>one of your clients</client> so that you can set up emissions for each site. If your organization or customer has only one site, create an 'All sites' site.
checklist.AddSiteCRCollaboratorDetails: Add sites to <client>one of your clients</client> so that you can set up emissions for each site. If your customer has only one site, create an 'All sites' site.
checklist.AddSiteOrgaDetails: Add sites to your <orga>organization</orga> so that you can set up emissions for each site. If your organization has only one site, create an 'All sites' site.
checklist.CreateFirstStudyDetails: Let's get started with your first Bilan Carbone®! Fill in the initial details, such as the date, name...
checklist.CreateFirstEmissionSourceDetails: Go to the first item/sub-item you wish to enter! Choose your emission factor, enter your activity data and make your first calculations.
checklist.ConsultResultsDetails: Now go to the "Results" page to view and export your emissions...
checklist.finished: You're ready to start using BC+! Feel free to consult the <faq>FAQ</faq> or contact us if you need anything.

formation.title: Training
formation.explanation: You will find below the training course for updating the BC V8 to V9 method. Watch the videos, take the quiz and receive your attestation! The videos take approximately 2 hours to watch. You can then take the test, which lasts up to {time} minutes, whenever you like. This training is available year-round.
formation.warningMessage:
Please check your BC+ account to see the name of your organisation on the My Organisation > Global informations page, as well as your first and last name in your profile (top right). This information will be used to generate your attestation.

You are currently logged in as {name}, from organisation {organization} with a level of {level}. If this last information is not correct, please contact our support.

Remember: the course must be taken with your personal account and your nominative e-mail address, and not with a generic company account. You can add other members of your organisation from the BC+: My organisation > My team page.
formation.videoExplanation: Please note that the assessment associated with this 'condensed' training course does not contain any traps if you watch the training carefully. Successful completion will allow you to obtain a free updated training certificate. However, an insufficient result would mean that you will have to reintegrate into the full training course (new Initiation module if you were trained M1 on V8, or new Professional module if you were trained M2 on V8).
formation.evaluationSubtitle: Please complete the knowledge assessment questionnaire to receive your v9 training attestation. It is limited in time and you will have <error>at most {time} minutes to answer the question. You can only answer the questionnaire once. Once you've started, you can't go back.</error>
formation.acceptation: I've understood that I'll only be able to launch the questionnaire once and that I'll have a limited amount of time to answer the question. I'm in the right conditions to start my test
formation.alertMessage: You only have 10 minutes remaining. After 10 minutes, this form will remain available and you will be able to submit your answers. However, if you take too long, your answers will not be taken into account and you will not receive a attestation of achievement.

forbidden.title: Blocked access
forbidden.message: You are not in our database of trained members, so you cannot access the training tab to take the refresher training course. If you believe this is an error, please follow the process outlined in our <link>FAQ</link>.

deactivableFeatures.title: Deactivable functionnalities
deactivableFeatures.Not authorized: You are not allowed to do this action

feedback.title: Give your opinion about BC+ !
feedback.body: If you have 5 minutes, we'd love to hear your feedback on BC+! This will help us to meet your needs as effectively as possible in our future developments. If this isn't a good time, you can delay your answer.
